#Text=Lynching of Joe Coe
#Text=For the early Latter Day Saint leader , see Joseph Coe .
#Text=Joe Coe , also known as George Smith , was an African-American laborer who was lynched on October 10 , 1891 , in Omaha , Nebraska .
#Text=Overwhelmed by a mob of one thousand at the Douglas County Courthouse , the twelve city police officers stood by without intervening .
#Text=Afterward , the mayor called the lynching " the most deplorable thing that has ever happened in the history of the country . " [ 1 ]
#Text=Biography and death
#Text=Coe was a married man with two children who lived on North 12th Street north of downtown Omaha .
#Text=On October 7 , 1891 , Lizzie Yates , a five-year-old white child who also lived in North Omaha , accused Coe of assaulting her .
#Text=Before the verdict was passed rumors swept through Omaha about Coe getting away with the crime , about the girl dying , and about Coe receiving a small punishment .
#Text=A crowd of men was already gathered at the old Douglas County Courthouse the day when Coe was brought in , to witness an unrelated , scheduled hanging , an official execution .
#Text=Rumors flew around Omaha that the girl had died , the guilty party was in jail , and was only going to be punished with 20 years ' incarceration . [ 2 ]
#Text=The next day , a mob of several hundred to 1,000 men formed in downtown Omaha early on October 10 and overwhelmed the police at the courthouse . [ 3 ]
#Text=Councilman Moriarty drove his cane through a window and led the men against the courthouse . [ 4 ]
#Text=Leaders drove Coe to the assumed victim 's house in the Near North Side neighborhood to be identified by the parents .
#Text=The mother immediately said she had seen Coe roaming around the house , although she would not swear that it was him . [ 4 ]
#Text=When the mob brought Coe back to the courthouse to be lynched , James E. Boyd , the governor of Nebraska , and the county sheriff both appealed to the men to disperse .
#Text=Instead , by midnight a crowd of 1,000 to 10,000 people had gathered at the courthouse . [ 5 ]
#Text=The mob beat Coe and dragged him through city streets .
#Text=He was probably already dead when he was hung from a streetcar wire at 17th and Harney Streets . [ 6 ]
#Text=Omaha mayor Richard C. Cushing quickly condemned the lynching as " the most deplorable thing that has ever happened in the history of the country . " [ 7 ]
#Text=Aftermath
#Text=Seven men were arrested for the crime , including the chief of police and the manager of a large dry goods store .
#Text=A mob gathered outside the jail and threatened to destroy it unless the suspects were freed on bail but the County Attorney was determined to refuse them . [ 8 ]
#Text=The following day when Coe 's body was set for public viewing at a downtown mortuary , six thousand spectators filed by .
#Text=Hucksters sold pieces of the lynching rope as souvenirs . [ 9 ]
#Text=Ten days after the lynching , the Douglas County Assistant Coroner testified in court that Smith died of " fright " , rather than of the wounds inflicted on him by the mob .
#Text=Those wounds included sixteen wounds to his body and three vertebrae broken in his spine .
#Text=Despite this , the coroner testified , " [ T]he heart was so contracted and the blood was in such a condition that the doctor was satisfied that the man was literally scared to death . "
#Text=County Attorney Mahoney said he would have to modify the charges against the lynchers . [ 10 ]
#Text=The grand jury decided not to prosecute .
